Regular Expressions in TOC

Examples¶

This section provides worked examples progressing from basic to advanced regular expressions. Each example includes step-by-step explanations and language descriptions.

Basic Examples¶

Example 1: Simple Characters¶

Regular Expression: \(abc\)

Language: \(L(abc) = \{abc\}\)

Description: Matches exactly the string “abc”

Explanation

This is the simplest case - literal concatenation of symbols. The language contains only one string.

Example 2: Union/Alternation¶

Regular Expression: \(a + b\)

Language: \(L(a + b) = \{a, b\}\)

Description: Matches either “a” or “b”

Step-by-step

  1. \(L(a) = \{a\}\)

  2. \(L(b) = \{b\}\)

  3. \(L(a + b) = L(a) \cup L(b) = \{a\} \cup \{b\} = \{a, b\}\)

Example 3: Kleene Star¶

Regular Expression: \(a^*\)

Language: \(L(a^*) = \{\epsilon, a, aa, aaa, aaaa, \ldots\}\)

Description: Zero or more repetitions of “a”

Understanding Kleene Star

  • \((L(a))^0 = \{\epsilon\}\) (zero repetitions)

  • \((L(a))^1 = \{a\}\) (one repetition)

  • \((L(a))^2 = \{aa\}\) (two repetitions)

  • \(L(a^*) = \bigcup_{i=0}^{\infty} (L(a))^i\)

Intermediate Examples¶

Example 4: Combining Operations¶

Regular Expression: \((a + b)^*\)

Language: All strings over alphabet \(\{a, b\}\)

Description: Any sequence of a’s and b’s, including empty string

Detailed Analysis

  1. \(L(a + b) = \{a, b\}\)

  2. \(L((a + b)^*) = \{\epsilon, a, b, aa, ab, ba, bb, aaa, aab, \ldots\}\)

  3. This generates \(\Sigma^*\) where \(\Sigma = \{a, b\}\)

Example 5: Specific Patterns¶

Regular Expression: \(ab^*c\)

Language: Strings starting with “a”, followed by zero or more “b”s, ending with “c”

Examples: \(\{ac, abc, abbc, abbbc, \ldots\}\)

Construction Process

  1. Start with \(a\): \(L(a) = \{a\}\)

  2. Concatenate with \(b^*\): \(L(ab^*) = \{a, ab, abb, abbb, \ldots\}\)

  3. Concatenate with \(c\): \(L(ab^*c) = \{ac, abc, abbc, abbbc, \ldots\}\)

Example 6: Multiple Unions¶

Regular Expression: \(a^*b^* + c^*\)

Language: Either (zero or more a’s followed by zero or more b’s) OR (zero or more c’s)

Breaking Down the Union

  • \(L(a^*b^*) = \{\epsilon, a, b, aa, ab, bb, aaa, aab, abb, bbb, \ldots\}\)

  • \(L(c^*) = \{\epsilon, c, cc, ccc, \ldots\}\)

  • \(L(a^*b^* + c^*) = L(a^*b^*) \cup L(c^*)\)

  • Note: \(\epsilon\) appears in both, but union eliminates duplicates

Advanced Examples¶

Example 7: Complex Patterns¶

Regular Expression: \((a + b)^*a(a + b)^*\)

Language: All strings over \(\{a, b\}\) containing at least one “a”

Description: Any string that has at least one occurrence of the symbol “a”

Advanced Analysis

This pattern ensures at least one “a” by: 1. \((a + b)^*\) - any prefix 2. \(a\) - guaranteed “a” 3. \((a + b)^*\) - any suffix

Alternative representation: \(\Sigma^* - b^*\) (complement of strings with only b’s)

Example 8: Even/Odd Patterns¶

Regular Expression: \((aa)^*\)

Language: Strings with even number of a’s (including zero)

Examples: \(\{\epsilon, aa, aaaa, aaaaaa, \ldots\}\)

Pattern Recognition

This demonstrates how regular expressions can capture mathematical properties: - Even number = pairs of elements - \((aa)^*\) groups a’s in pairs - Only generates strings where |string| ≡ 0 (mod 2)

Example 9: Practical Application¶

Regular Expression: \((0 + 1)^*01(0 + 1)^*\)

Language: Binary strings containing “01” as a substring

Description: Any binary string that contains the pattern “01” somewhere

Real-World Connection

This type of pattern is useful for: - Finding specific bit patterns in computer science - Detecting state transitions (0→1) - Pattern matching in text processing

Structure: [any prefix][required pattern][any suffix]

Challenging Examples¶

Example 10: Multiple Constraints¶

Regular Expression: \(0^*(10^*10^*)^*\)

Language: Binary strings with even number of 1’s

Complex Pattern Analysis

Breaking down the structure: 1. \(0^*\) - optional leading zeros 2. \((10^*10^*)^*\) - pairs of 1’s separated by zeros 3. Each iteration of the outer star adds exactly two 1’s 4. Result: strings where number of 1’s ≡ 0 (mod 2)

Alternative Construction

This could also be built using state-based thinking: - State 0: even number of 1’s seen (accepting) - State 1: odd number of 1’s seen (non-accepting) - Transitions: 0 keeps state, 1 toggles state

Practice Problems¶

Try constructing regular expressions for these languages:

  1. Strings over \(\{a, b\}\) that start and end with the same symbol

  2. Binary strings representing multiples of 3

  3. Strings with no three consecutive identical characters

Hints for Practice Problems

  1. Consider cases: starts with a, starts with b

  2. Use modular arithmetic with 3 states

  3. Think about forbidden patterns and their complements

Next Steps¶
